Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: LTREB: Evolutionary Demography - the Contribution of Adaptation and Environment to Population Dynamics, Range Size, and Niche Width
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project continues a 7-year study of environmental and demographic variation across the geographic range of a native California plant in order to understand the ecological and evolutionary limits on an organism?s distribution. Prior work showed that environmental variables related to climate, soils, and interactions with insect pollinators and seed-eaters all change across the plant's range. Population growth rates, a measure of population viability, also decline toward the range edge. Over the next five years, research will examine the role that dormant seeds, which remain buried in the soil for 2-5 years, play in allowing populations to weather adverse environments and persist long-term. The project will also determine range-wide differences in the longevity of dormant seeds.

With impending climate change, parts of the current geographic range of many organisms are likely to become unsuitable for continued persistence. Understanding what limits species from colonizing unfavorable environments now can help forecast species responses to deteriorating conditions within their current range. In addition to its scientific impacts, the project will serve an important educational mission by engaging high school students, undergraduate students from research and primarily undergraduate institutions, and graduate students in research. Project leaders will work with high school students from a rural California high school and from a charter school in St Paul Minnesota through in-class activities and field projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research goals were to investigate the ecological and evolutionary causes of limits to a species’ geographic distribution, using the California annual plant, Clarkia xantiana ssp. xantiana as a model organism. An understanding of limits to species’ distribution can inform predictions of how distributions will change as climate changes. The research could be divided into four parts: 1) a long-term demographic study of thirty-five populations throughout the geographic range of the species to assess geographic variation in the population performance; 2) a long-term record of climate and environmental variables in order to assess the influence of climate and environment on demographic performance; 3) a long-term study of the influence of insect damage to plants on demographic performance; and 4) the spatial scale of local adaptation of populations to their home environment; local adaptation increases a population’s performance at its home site, increasing population persistence, but may reduce a population’s ability to colonize a new location. The study revealed that demographic performance of populations was highest in the center of the species geographic range and declined steadily toward the eastern range margin. Over the course of the study, populations throughout the range were affected by the severe 4-year drought that depressed population growth throughout the geographic range. These results suggest that changing climate will reduce the abundance of the species throughout its geographic range. In addition, the geographic limits of the species was found to be better correlated with extreme climate conditions, such as the drought, than to average climate conditions. Insect damage to plants varied geographically, being highest at the center of the range and lowest at the eastern range margin. The experimental work to establish the spatial scale of local adaptation has been completed and samples are being processed.

For our broader impacts, the research program contributed to the training of one postdoctoral fellow, three PhD students, five postgraduate students and eight undergraduate students through Cornell University. In addition, researchers partnered annually with a rural high school in California to introduce biology students to research on environmental change and on pollination biology.  Researchers also established connections with a Magnet Middle School, introducing students to population studies of native plants and the role of climate in affecting plant distribution and abundance.
